original_title: Sri Lanka rupee closes down at 336/341 to the US dollar
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka rupee closed at 336/341 to the US to the US dollar Tuesday in the spot market, down from 320/328 to the US dollar, dealers said.
The rupee appreciated steeply after the central bank lifted a surrender rule ending a guided peg, leading to heavy selling by dollar holders and banks.
Banks that oversold dollars can now make profits by covering their position, analysts said.
Related Sri Lanka to operate ad hoc exchange rate peg from March 07
The central bank is now operating an ad hoc peg without a transparent predetermined path, without any assurance that dollars it buys from the market is sold back to maintain exchange rate stability.
Under the earlier guided peg, the central bank sold dollars back, and due to a private credit contraction it started to sell lower levels of dollars than it bought in the last quarter.

When a central bank buys dollars it creates new rupees. If the holders of the new rupees spend the money especially on imports, the agency has to sell back the dollars and take back the liquidity to keep the exchange rate stable.
However under an ad hoc peg or intermediate regime there is no obligation for the central bank to sell back dollars it bought, and can make the rupee depreciate even without strong domestic credit.

When private credit is strong, such central banks will re-inject money to maintain its policy rate and trigger more demand for dollars, rapidly running down reserves and triggering a full blown currency crisis.
Intermediate regimes are found in all countries that suffer monetary instability and go to the IMF.
Because intermediate regimes are not changed to consistent credible regimes, like a hard peg or a clean float with a low inflation target, they keep going to the IMF again and again.
Several of them, which got market access in recent years with exceptionally low US interest rates, have now defaulted. (Colombo/Mar15/2023)
